reviews.author: kentanggoreng
reviews.title: Horrible instructors
reviews.comment_content: The content of the course is quite interesting; you learn about the ocean, how currents, wind, etc works and their correlation with productivity and biodiversity. Then it moves on to marine animals from bacteria, plankton to mammals. Finally it discusses about marine biomes like intertidal, subtidal and estuary.
reviews.comment_teaching: The course starts with Qian. He's alright; he's an expert in marine biology so he knows a lot of stuff. He is like a grandfather you always know --- talks too slow, talks gibberish most of the time, often doesn't make sense. Wang was bad ---- most of what he talks about doesn't have any content. It took serious effort to really focus on the classes. As bad as Wang, nobody beats Liu, he was horrendous. I gave up going to class because he was THAT bad. He's uninspiring, lectures are boring, very unprofessional and lazy. Don't even bother to go to his paperchecks because he's so lazy to change your grades, he would make ridiculous and stupid excuses to weigh your answers down.
reviews.comment_grading: Grading is alright I suppose, as long as you study properly. People usually screw up because the instructors are horrible and the lecture notes are as bad; so make sure you got a hold of a library book.
reviews.comment_workload: 35% midterm and 65% finals. The weighing is VERY SCARY so be careful for the finals.

reviews.author: JJLL
reviews.title: Marine Biology
reviews.comment_content:
This course aims to introduce several concepts about marine biology. Here are the following:

1. History of Marine Biology Research
2. Introduction to Marine Environment
3. Microbial diversity, function and processes
4. Primary Producers & Primary Productivity
in Ocean
5. Harmful Algal Blooms and Possible
Mechanisms
6. Interaction among microscopic organisms –
microbial loops
7. Zooplankton and planktonic food webs
8. Biogeochemical cycles in marine
ecosystems
9. Survey of major marine taxa
10. Sponges and Corals
11. Coral Reef Ecology/symbiosis
12. Marine Molluscs and shell formation
13. Arthropods & Echinoderms
14. Oyster and Shrimp farming
15. Marine Fishes & Fisheries in Hong Kong  
16. Marine Mammals and Mammal
Conservation
19. Indicator species of Marine Pollution  
20. Between the tides
21. Rocky shores
22. Sandy Beach & Mudflat
23. Estuary
24. Chemosynthetic ecosystems

Students are required to digest every single topic. More importantly, they are emphasized in connecting several topics and asking questions to explore the "ocean world".
reviews.comment_teaching:
Generally, all three teachers have different teaching styles.

Prof. Qian Peiyuan:
As a head professor in Ocean Science, he shared many ideas on different aspects of ocean science, including the controversy in sea otters controlling the sea urchin and abalone population, the ways for animals survive on beaches, mudflats. He does not follow the order of the PowerPoint. Therefore, students are required to study the lecture notes before the lessons. (This method can also apply to other courses so that the revision workload can reduce.)

Prof Liu Hongbin:
He is like a typical professor in HKUST. He follows the lecture slides and explains some difficult concepts. However, his voice is a bit low so it is recommended to sit in front of him.

Prof Cheng Jinping:
Her discussion topics are the hardest for me as there are several unfamiliar concepts for BCB students. Her mainland accent sometimes is hard to comprehend. Luckily, her part of the exam mostly follows the lecture notes.
reviews.comment_grading:
The grading system is as follows:
 Group project (5 students/group): 30%
o Written Commentary: 15%
o Oral presentation: 15%
 Each  group  will  submit  one  5-mins  video  to  present  their
project
 Final Examination: 65%
 Class attendance: 5%

My final grade: A
I heard that getting at least a great grade (B or above) can be challenging. As mentioned earlier, students need to be familiar with every topic as much as possible. Due to the pandemic, we only have one exam, covering all the topics. I also saw the grading system in the professor office accidentally. (Trust me, quite a lot of B to C.)

The final exam consists of 3 parts: T/F, Short questions, One-page "Essay/ Matching/Table". Be careful that some short questions and T/F questions contain the sharing from the professors. Jotting notes are necessary. BE CAREFUL about the matching of terminology (It may be present in the final exams in the future). If you are not the expert in terminology, DO NOT ATTEMPT IT!

The most deceptive one is class attendance. I would like to give a C here because of it. Professors can give sudden quizzes and take photos to have evidence on the overview of the attendance. Asking questions seems a great way to earn points.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is quite heavy in general.

For the group project, it is recommended to start the project as soon as possible after finding the teammates. Making a 5- minute video can be easier said than done since you need to filter a lot of information.

For the final exam, reading lecture materials, attending classes and google searching for specific terms are strongly advised. Besides, obviously, DO NOT START REVISING THE LECTURE MATERIALS TWO WEEKS BEFORE THE EXAM. IT WOULD BE MUCH BETTER TO REVISE THE NOTES RIGHT AFTER THE LECTURE!

reviews.comment_teaching:
Qian: Lots of personal sharing during class, talks really slow, and lots of slides with pictures only. I attended the lectures at first but would always doze off (it's 9am with his slow pace lecturing...) Lec4-7 are more or less things learned from LIFS2060 (biodiversity) so its okay to simply reverse the slides and take a look at the 2060 notes

Liu: His slides are relatively more informative and helpful. Part 3 is also more difficult so it's better to either be in class or watch lecture videos. I watched lecture videos with 2x speed instead of jotting notes while in class.
reviews.comment_grading:
【Group poster project (5 students/group): 35% 】
o Poster content: 15%
o Poster design: 5%
o Oral presentation skill of poster: 10%
Each group will have 5 mins of oral presentation + 3 mins of Q & A
o Personal effort: 5%
Each student will be evaluated by his/her group members, based on personal contribution to the group project （scores ranging from 0 - 5）

【Final Examination: 65%】
After the add-drop period, prof. Qian suddenly released an announcement with the following text :

"As I have already mentioned in early lectures, we will pay attention to attendance of the lectures by individuals (as there is a record of class attendance of each lecture.  We will randomly select some records, which will be used for final grade adjustment. "

I have no idea whether the professors can actually adjust the grading system after the add-drop period and whether they did adjust our grades according to our attendance. Just find it ridiculous.

【for your reference】
group project: 24.75/30
peer evaluation: 5/5
final: 79/100 (mean= 75.55; s.d.=10.51)
total: 81.1/100 (mean= 79.31; s.d.= 7.18)
grade: B

the grading is not as bad but with the bad teaching and messy instructions, better to avoid than take unless neccesary.
reviews.comment_workload:
The workload is not very big but miserable.

The guidelines for the group project were not very clear. We were given a few topics to choose from and had to make a poster. But then Prof. Liu mentioned something about a PowerPoint to facilitate our presentation. By the end, most groups just showed the poster from around 30s and then used a PowerPoint to present. My group decided to present with the poster like how prezi works and the professors end up saying we put too little info/ too few graphics on the poster.

Got really confused because the PowerPoint should not have been the aid to present but anyway... their advice also changes every time we ask them so... I guess they just say what they think at the moment and would forget right away.

About the final exam... we asked whether we can google and the professors only said "you won't have time for it". No one knows whether it is allowed or not.

If you are still taking it online, prepare a cheat sheet to jot down the things you learned in class. It will help you with your finals. It's open book anyway.

reviews.author: Sunny_nym
reviews.title: A great course for students who have the passion of marine biology
reviews.comment_content:
Interesting topics for an undergraduate student to learn about the marine biology.

Professor Liu:
Introduction to Marine Environment
Physical and Chemical Oceanography
Virus, bacteria, archaea
Cyanobacteria and protists
Primary Producers (phytoplankton and macroalgae)
Zooplankton
Marine Mammals
Primary Productivity in Ocean
Harmful Algal Blooms and Possible Mechanisms
Food web dynamics  

Ms Cheng Jin Ping (Guest lecturer):
Marine Fishes

Professor Wang:
Cnidarian and worms
Marine molluscs
Marine arthropods
Marine arthropods
Echinoderms

Professor Qian (Course coordinator):
Coral Reef Ecology
Intertidal ecology
Subtidal benthic communities
Estuary
Hydrothermal vent and Cold seeps
Biogeochemical cycles in marine ecosystems
reviews.comment_teaching:
Professor Wang's lectures were well-prepared. He thought of some interesting examples to illustrate the concepts that made students understand more easily.

Professor Qian's lectures were fruitful. He talked about marine environments and some biogeochemical cycles in the marine ecosystems. I think you should sit at the back of the classroom if you are having his lectures as he always turns the volume too loud that you may feel a little bit annoyed.

Professor Liu had a relatively casual teaching style when comparing to other lecturers. His slides were sometimes lacked information that you have to pay extra attention in his lectures. You may need to jot down sufficient amount of notes for your study in the future.
reviews.comment_grading: I got within SD+1 above mean and within SD-1 below mean. Finally got a B from this course. Quite a good grade already comparing to other life science courses.
reviews.comment_workload:
You have to be alert with the mid-term examination as there were 2-3 essay questions to be answered with. That means you may be required to memorise some special terms that have mentioned in the lectures.

Regular revision is advised for B grade or above.

reviews.author: guessmewho
reviews.comment_content:
Midterm covers different classes of marine organisms. You need to memorize the structure and function of different organisms. There will be mainly MC and short essay questions. Not too difficult if you have enough revision. Questions are quite strict forward, but be careful to also look at the graphs in lecture notes, make sure you don't miss any details.

Second half of the lecture is taught by Prof. Qian and Hongbin. The format of final is similar to midterm, with MC and 4 essay questions. I think Qian's questions are more challenging, he likes to ask something not found or taught in lecture. You need to fully understand and integrate your knowledge to answer his questions. But don't worry too much, we only need to answer 4 out of 5 essay questions.
reviews.comment_teaching:
Hongbin's lectures are boring. He is more like talking to himself but not to the class. But his lecture notes are very details, enough for you to understand everything covered in exams, so his lectures in my opinion is optional.

WANG only taught before midterm and I don't really remember his teaching. I think his part is normal and fair. With a little bit accent but still easy to understand.

QIAN's lecture notes are super messy and not so organised. It is important to attend his class because he might talk something not included in notes but appear in exams. He loves to spend most of his time talking about one particular page and then go through the rest swiftly.
reviews.comment_grading: The marking of exams are quite generous on essay questions. The mean is high. I got 86/100 in midterm, and 93/100 in final, and overall I got an A.
reviews.comment_workload:
midterm 48%
Final 50%
Quiz 2%

The quiz is conducted suddenly, but since it contributes only 2 %, it is okay if you miss it. It asked something about the previous lecture notes.

Qian is quite interesting and engages well with students. Liu does not explain very clearly sometimes, and Wang's lectures are extremely boring.
All 3 professors upload very detailed and good lecture notes which are helpful for revision after exams.
reviews.comment_grading:
Midterm: 35%
Final: 60%
Not sure about the other 5%?

The exams are quite easy. MCQs, true and false, short questions, and 3 long questions in each exam. Very basic exams, should be easy if you revise every lecture note before the exam.

I got 91.5 in midterm (>1 SD above mean), 58 in final (below mean, did not have time to revise half the topics for final). Total 69 = mean = grade B-.
